User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:9.0a1) Gecko/20110907 Firefox/9.0a1
Build ID: 20110907030853

Steps to reproduce:

If you unpack a firefox tarball on a linux install with missing required libraries, executing firefox results in totally unhelpful error messages being produced.


Actual results:

./firefox
XPCOMGlueLoad error for file /home/mcpherrin/nightly/libxpcom.so:
libxul.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
Couldn't load XPCOM

LD_LIBRARY_PATH=`pwd` ./firefox
XPCOMGlueLoad error for file /home/mcpherrin/nightly/libxpcom.so:
libasound.so.2: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
Couldn't load XPCOM.
On installing alsa-lib, firefox loaded normally.

Using a 64-bit build without 32-bit compatibility libraries installed produces an even more insane error:

/home/mcpherrin/32bit/firefox-bin: no such file or directory


Expected results:

We should probably have some more user-friendly message of some sort.

comments.text:
I suspect the latter (firefox-bin: no such file or directory) is coming from your shell, not us. The XPCOMGlueLoad one might be fixable, but I'm guessing the problem comes from dlopen or such on libxpcom.so, and getting a more detailed diagnosis might require trudging through library dependencies ourselves.

I wouldn't want to invest too much time on this, since most users are going to get their Firefox preinstalled from their distro, and it will probably still Just Work for most linux distros (I'm curious what you're running).

A SUMO article (with some good GoogleFu ranking) describing how to track down the problem yourself would be a fine first start either way, though.
